Applied Beer Analysis

My neighbor's beer is best anyway!

Have you ever asked yourself if you love Guiness in Ireland as much as you love it at home? Or have you ever asked yourself how the Irish rate their most famous beer compared to you or people from other countries? And how do we all express our feelings about different beers compared to each other? If you like to learn more about how beer preferences and descriptions are influenced by geography and cultural background, then do not hesitate to click on the below displayed button and get a profound insight in the beer rating world and the beer rating biases induced by rater's origin.

Start Story

Some differences occur! Why? Attempt to remove user bias by rescaling the ratings per user. (Kasimir will do) TODO: method for Countries-dist -> describe rescaling Somewhat fails (again report numbers using a table!) Maybe due to the beers rated by country/state? Next idea: look at most rated beers per state and country:

Our data is skewed. Global average is not representative for the actual quality of beers. Indeed, very different beers rated per country Significant in global ratings for top beers versus countries/states (Kasimir will do) (Add a table!)

Motivate propensity analysis. We need to match on beers and users at the same time. (Matrix factorization! - we’ll see how detailed…)

There is a small difference overall, we look per country:

Discuss results. Note: Belgium, US: top (big beer drinking countries) (Matthieu will do)

Motivate look at language: Is this bias reflected in language? Foreign vs local beers (Oisin will do) [give numbers] -> Move to more general language analysis Do countries talk differently?

Discuss: why different…

Some differences, can we cluster countries or states based on language?

Discuss

Discuss

Key bullet points and takeaways (Table)

  • Countries rate differently (a lot of it is due to user bias)
  • Countries rate different beers (they have different quality)
  • Propensity matching (Matthieu: is there more to say?)
  • Countries talk differently about beer
  • Cultural difference is not entirely geographical (network)
